RecordModule#

class RecordModule(step_time: float, duration: float)[source]#

Bases: DimensionalModule

Module with support for buffers and parameters with time-based indexing.

Parameters:

  • step_time (float) – length of time between stored values in the record.

  • duration (float) – length of time over which prior values are stored.

Caution

When restoring from a state dictionary, the “pointer” to the next time slice to overwrite is preserved along with the names of added constrained buffers and parameters, but the step time and duration are not.

aligned(name: str, latest_first: bool = True, offset: int = 1) → Tensor[source]#

Full aligned record of a recorded tensor.

The native storage order is latest data at the last index (after being aligned with torch.roll()). By default this will return the latest data at the first index.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • latest_first (bool, optional) – if the most recent slice should be at the zeroth index. Defaults to True.

  • offset (int, optional) – window index offset as number of steps prior to the location of the next time slice to overwrite. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

_description_

Return type:

torch.Tensor

deregister_constrained(name: str)[source]#

Deregisters a buffer or parameter as constrained.

If the name given isn’t a constrained buffer or parameter, calling this does nothing.

Parameters:

name (str) – fully-qualified string name of the buffer or parameter to register.

property dt: float#

Length of time between stored values in history.

In the same units as self.duration.

Parameters:

value (float) – new time step length.

Returns:

length of the time step.

Return type:

float

Note

If a reconstrain() operation needs to be performed, all state will be overwritten with zeros.

property duration: float#

Length of time over which prior values are stored.

In the same units as self.dt.

Parameters:

value (float) – new length of the history to store.

Returns:

length of the record.

Return type:

float

Note

If a reconstrain() operation needs to be performed, all state will be overwritten with zeros.

latest(name: str, offset: int = 1) → Tensor[source]#

Retrieves the most recent slice of a constrained attribute.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • offset (int, optional) – number of steps before present to select from. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

most recent slice of the tensor selected.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

reconstrain(dim: int, size: int | None) → RecordModule[source]#

Modifies constraints.

Adding constraints will not modify the constrained tensors, whereas modifying an existing constraint will create a new zero-tensor with the shape of that dimension modified.

If the tensor was modified to be compatible with the new constraint ahead of time (i.e. if liveconstrain is False and was set with its new value), then reallocation will not occur.

Parameters:

  • dim (int) – dimension to which a constraint should be added, removed, or modified.

  • size (int | None) – size of the new constraint, None if the constraint is to be removed.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – constrained buffer or parameter is no longer a compatible shape.

  • RuntimeError – constrained buffer or parameter would not be valid after the change in constraints.

Returns:

self.

Return type:

RecordModule

record(name: str, value: Tensor, offset: int = 0) → None[source]#

Overwrites the record at the current slice and increments the pointer.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • value (torch.Tensor) – value to write into the current time step.

  • offset (int, optional) – number of steps before present to update. Defaults to 0.

property recordsz: int#

Number of stored time slices for each record tensor.

Returns:

length of the record, in number of slices.

Return type:

int

register_constrained(name: str) → None[source]#

Registers an existing buffer or parameter as constrained.

Parameters:

name (str) – fully-qualified string name of the buffer or parameter to register.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – shape of the buffer or parameter is invalid.

  • AttributeError – attribute is not a registered buffer or parameter.

Caution

A registered Parameter with a value of None cannot be constrained as it is not returned by get_parameter().

reset(name: str, data: Any) → None[source]#

Resets a constrained attribute to some value or values.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute to target.

  • data (Any) – data to insert.

select(name: str, time: float | Tensor, interp: Interpolation, *, tolerance: float | Tensor = 1e-07, offset: int = 1) → Tensor[source]#

Selects elements of a constrained attribute based on prior time.

If time is a scalar and is within tolerance of an integer index, then a slice will be returned without ever attempting interpolation.

If time is a tensor, interpolation will be called regardless, and the time passed into the interpolation call will be set to either 0 or self.dt. Interpolation results are then overwritten with exact values before returning. If time is a tensor, then tolerance can also be a tensor.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – name of the attribute from which to select.

  • time (float | torch.Tensor) – time(s) before present to select from.

  • interp (Interpolation) – method to interpolate between discrete time steps.

  • tolerance (float | torch.Tensor, optional) – maximum difference in time from a discrete sample to consider a time co-occuring with the sample. Defaults to 1e-7.

  • offset (int, optional) – window index offset as number of steps prior to the location of the next time slice to overwrite. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

interpolated values selected at a prior time(s).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

Shape

time:

\(N_0 \times \cdots \times [D]\)

return:

\(N_0 \times \cdots \times [D]\)

Where:

  • \(N_0, \ldots\) are the dimensions of the constrained tensor.

  • \(D\) is the number of times for each value to select.

Tip

Mimicing the behavior of torch.gather(), if time is out of the valid range, a ValueError will be thrown. To avoid this, clamp time like time.clamp(0, module.duration).
